text: English grammar lesson 16 it's time now
to talk about imperative sentences
sentences like open it
the imperative uses the base verb to ask
a person to perform an action
the imperative often is used as a
command open it but we could also use
the imperative to make a request please
open it how to report imperative
sentences that's just one of the
questions we'll answer in this lesson
in this lesson we'll answer these two
questions how do we report imperative
sentences what other reporting verbs can
we use besides say tell and ask as I
mentioned imperative sentences are used
to do different things we can give
commands or orders come here now give
directions turn left on 5th Avenue give
instructions write your account number
on your check make requests please show
the client in and issue warnings don't
feed your dog candy but how do we report
imperative sentences let's look at one
of our examples a request please show
the client in said mr. wells to the
receptionist the reported statement is
mr. wells told the receptionist to show
the client in so when reporting
imperative sentences we most often use
this form who our speaker tell or ask
the reporting verb usually in the past
tense whom the object and the infinitive
again our example is mr. wells told the
receptionist to show the client in let's
try our first exercise exercise one
report each imperative sentence using
tell or ask and an infinitive example
make a wish what did the mother say we
already have the speaker in a reporting
verb the mother told whom her daughter
and the infinitive to make the mother
told her daughter to make a wish
now you try number one one
enjoy your youth son what did the father
say answer the father told his son to
enjoy his youth to don't go too fast and
have an accident on your birthday what
did the father say answer the father
told his son not to go too fast and have
an accident on his birthday three dance
with me it's my birthday what did the
man say answer the man asked the woman
to dance with him because it was his
birthday because there are so many uses
of the imperative we don't have to limit
ourselves to the reporting verbs tell
and ask in reported speech there are
many others to choose from let's
consider some examples
come to my party example one Jennifer
invited us to come to her party don't
tell me you have other plans example two
Jennifer warned us not to tell her we
had other plans don't be late
example three Jennifer warned us not to
be late or Jennifer reminded us to be on
time when choosing other reporting verbs
besides the most common ones of say-tell
and ask you need to think about these
two questions what verb most accurately
reports the nature of the speaker's
words so focus on meaning what grammar
is required by the reporting verb think
about structure I'd like to present
other reporting verbs to you now and
I'll group them by meaning by focusing
on the speaker's purpose you can choose
an accurate reporting verb you can use
tell or ask to report a request it may
be more accurate to choose a verb like
plead or
urge invitations can be reported with
ask but you could also try invite
commands and orders can be reported with
tell you might also choose command
demand order or wish to be more accurate
directions and instructions can be
reported with tell or you may try advise
caution instruct or recommend these are
- some suggestions for questions you
might use ask inquire question or wonder
as you're reporting verb responses can
use answer clarify confirm explain
insist reply respond and here are even
more reporting verbs for you to consider
verbs to report neutral statements verbs
to report emotional statements
verbs to report purposeful statements
now I'm not going to give examples for
all of these verbs and if some are
unfamiliar to you you can look them up
in a dictionary these lists are really
just a reference for you now let's
consider reporting verbs from the
viewpoint of structure some reporting
verbs will call them group a use this
structure it's the reporting verb plus
an object whom plus the infinitive it's
the same structure used for ask and tell
ask someone to do something tell someone
to do something now you can use the
structure with these verbs advise
encourage forbid invite instruct order
remind request urge and warn again I
won't give examples this is just a
reference in group B we have verbs that
are followed by an infinitive agree to
do something big to do something claim
to do something etc now some verbs
belong to more than one group for
example Baig and promise can also use
the structure we saw in group a you can
beg or promise someone to do something
and a lot of these verbs can simply be
followed by a that Clause as in she
swore that she was telling the truth
in Group C we have verbs followed by a
gerund the ing form of a verb for
example acknowledge doing something
admit doing something advise is a verb
that belongs to both Group C and a so we
can advise doing something and we could
advise someone to do something in Group
D we have reporting verbs followed by an
object whom followed by a preposition
followed by a gerund
for example accuse someone of doing
something other verbs in this group are
blame dissuade congratulate forgive and
warn there are others again these lists
are
complete but they're a good reference
for you in our last group Group II
reporting verbs are followed by that
plus the base verb this is a more formal
structure also known as the subjunctive
it's very typical in writing let's use
an example with proposed the manager
proposed that all employees be given
equal vacation time let's try one more
exercise exercise to listen to each
statement then identify which reported
statement is most accurate happy
birthday which is most accurate a
Jennifer wished me a happy birthday be
Jennifer requested that I have a happy
birthday see Jennifer promised me to
have a happy birthday well the purpose
of that statement was not to make a
request or promise but rather to express
a wish so a is most accurate why don't
we have the party outside which is most
accurate a Jennifer demanded that we
have the party outside be Jennifer
suggested that we have the party outside
see Jennifer threatened to have the
party outside answer be
I'm over 30 in fact I'm closer to 40
which is most accurate a Jennifer
confessed that she's over 30 in fact she
admitted to being closer to 40 B
Jennifer argued that she's over 30 and
fact she denied being closer to 40 C
Jennifer recalled that she's over 30 in
fact she consented to be closer to 40
answer a have a nice day
which is most accurate a Jennifer wished
us a nice day be Jennifer congratulated
us on a nice day see Jennifer guaranteed
that we would have a nice day answer a a
follow-up exercise to this lesson is
available exclusively at English cafe
comm my user name is Jennifer ESL
well we've reached the end of our lesson
and this is all to the end of our series
on reported speech thanks for watching
and happy studies
